item.title: Connect Four bot competition
item.description: Years ago when I worked at Yodle the engineering team held a Connect Four bot competition. The goal was for each person to write a Connect Four playing bot and then let them loose to determine the winner. We had either a few days or a few weeks to do this and my failed approach was to use genetic programming to evolve a bot. The best it did was beat a completely random bot 80% of the time while the winning entry leveraged Minimax with Alpha Beta Pruning.

item.title: Secure at the network level
item.description: Two weeks ago Travis CI published a postmortem describing an outage that was caused by a script that truncated all tables on a production database. The script was designed to run against a test database but instead ended up wiping the production one. The remediation steps highlighted are a great start but Iâ€™m surprised they didnâ€™t pick the most obvious one - protect systems at the network level. Relying on confirmation steps, user permissions, and unique credentials per environment are great steps and should be best practices but they donâ€™t actually stop malicious or accidental behavior.

item.title: Load testing
item.description: I started writing this post about using Siege to do load testing but got carried away and ended up discovering how much I donâ€™t know. In particular, I ended up stumbling unto Gil Teneâ€™s talk on measuring latency and how nearly every tool gets it wrong due to the bias in the tools themselves. The general idea is that most tools measure service time rather than request time. Service time is how long it takes your application to handle a request while request time is the time it takes for the user to receive a response.

item.title: Open sourcing self driving car data
item.description: Thereâ€™s a rush by the worldâ€™s largest companies to develop the first fully self driving car. The investment so far has been insane and itâ€™s only the start. Itâ€™s one of those problems that get more and more difficult to solve the closer they are to the finish. The upside is so large that it also leads to some perverse behavior in order to get any advantage - the Uber/Waymo lawsuit comes to mind here.

item.title: Protecting data ouside of a Terms of Service
item.description: Since the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica news broke Iâ€™ve been thinking about how a company can make private data available without depending on a terms of service to enforce its usage or retention. As weâ€™ve seen, terms of service are easily ignored and it may take years to notice that your data has been compromised. item.title: Facebook's "breach"
item.description: The big news this weekend was that Facebook suspended Cambridge Analytica, a company that leveraged behavioral data to come up with very focused and accurate political ads, for using data that they were not supposed to have as well as not deleting it when caught. Everyone seems to be surprised by this revelation but Iâ€™m honestly surprised it took this long and I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if there are still hundreds, or even thousands, of companies in the same situation as Cambridge Analytica, albeit at a smaller scale.

item.title: Crowdsourced data
item.description: Open source has become a critical part of modern software development that allows small teams to move quickly and do in months what used to take years. This has been driven by massive platforms, such as GitHub, that make it extremely easy to find useful code, contribute back, and provide feedback, comments, and requests. Unfortunately, data hasnâ€™t seen as strong of an open sourcing trend. There are a few sites - ranging from data.

item.title: Hunting for my old GeoCities site
item.description: One of my first exposures to the web was geocities and I recall creating a site on GeoCities under the â€œCape Canaveralâ€ space. And I only remembered that when I stumbled across OoCities.org and saw the name. Being a kid I was really into space and astronomy and created my GeoCities within that space. I keep trying to find my page but am constantly disappointed when every attempt ends in failure - although you do run into some amazing sites from the early years of the web.

item.title: Retrieving Kindle highlights
item.description: At this point Iâ€™ve moved most the majority of my reading to a Kindle. If I want to read a book Iâ€™ll only get a physical version if the Kindle version is unavailable. Itâ€™s often cheaper, immediately available, takes up no space, and comes with a variety of annotation abilities. My biggest frustration has been how difficult itâ€™s been to export my highlights. item.title: Analyzing AWS ELB logs
item.description: Logging HTTP requests should be enabled for every application you run. When things go wrong, and they will, itâ€™s often the first step to understand the problem. The documentation is up on the Amazon site but thereâ€™s a surprising amount of information thatâ€™s hidden away in the logs.

item.title: Optimize for keyboard shortcuts
item.description: Iâ€™m a big believer of offering keyboard-only experiences to your power users. Productivity applications are all about productivity and keyboard shortcuts are what give your users power and speed. The mouse and menus are easier for newcomers but those that stick with the application inevitably need the speed that comes from shortcuts. The ultimate example of this is Excel.

item.title: Making the most of the subway commute
item.description: Every day I take the subway to and from work and canâ€™t help but think how that time could be better spent. item.title: My follower factory
item.description: Last week, the New York Times ran an expose on the massive amount of follower fraud happening on Twitter. item.title: MoviePass: A fascinating business model
item.description: Given my lack of cultural knowledge the fact that Iâ€™ve heard of MoviePass should be a sign that itâ€™s a big deal. item.title: Design anti pattern: Tab switching autosave
item.description: Every once in awhile I get frustrated by a product experience and turn it into a design anti pattern rant. item.title: Phonetic distance
item.description: Last year I wrote a simple script to automate posting our On-Call schedule. item.title: Calendar query language
item.description: Iâ€™m a power user of Google Calendar and use it to organize meetings, tasks, and important dates. The one thing I wish it had was a more powerful query language. item.title: Learning Docker
item.description: Iâ€™m a bit embarrassed to admit this but Iâ€™ve been a bit behind the Docker craze. item.title: Favorite books of 2017

item.title: AR Adblocking

Weâ€™ll have a world of information at our fingertips and will end up with tools we canâ€™t even imagine. An idea Iâ€™ve been thinking about is an AR based adblock. item.title: Visualizing my 2017 stats
item.description: Over the past year Iâ€™ve been collecting a bunch of statistics for each of my days in the hope that Iâ€™ll have time to dig into them and discover some interesting patterns. Unfortunately I havenâ€™t had a chance to do anything other than some simple visualizations but even these provide some insight into my 2017. This isnâ€™t a wholehearted adoption of the quantified self movement but itâ€™s something I am interested in and hoping to expand in 2018.

item.title: People do what you inspect, not what you expect
item.description: While reading Who Says Elephants Canâ€™t Dance about the revival of IBM in the 90s I came across a simple, yet profound statement by Louis Gerstner: â€œPeople do what you inspect, not what you expect.â€ We hear variations of this constantly and itâ€™s true - if you want to drive behavior change you need to make sure thatâ€™s what youâ€™re actually measuring and holding people accountable for. Otherwise we all run the risk of preaching what we donâ€™t practice.

item.title: Send a shirt, get a shirt
item.description: Despite being an early tech adopter I avoid buying clothes online. The one service that I wish existed, and Iâ€™m sure it does somewhere, is a place where I can send some existing clothes that I know fit me perfectly and then have them used as the basis for new, custom made clothes.

item.title: Top posts of 2017
item.description: I use Google Analytics on my blog and now that the year is almost over itâ€™s time for the annual tradition of sharing the top posts of the year. item.title: My Medium experiment

item.title: Analyzing my blog: 2017 edition
item.description: I have a set of scripts I wrote in 2016 that aimed to analyze my posts over the years and hopefully offered up some insights. Iâ€™ve updated them for 2017 but rather than posting every single visualization I thought it would be more valuable to highlight the ones that seemed the most relevant and interesting. item.title: More intelligent credit card merchant rates
item.description: While reading todayâ€™s Stratechery update on Patreon changing their pricing model I came across the following passage: Of course this wasnâ€™t great for creators: payments made for a creation released on November 2 wouldnâ€™t land in creatorsâ€™ bank accounts until some time after December 1; the reasoning, though, was clear â€” credit card fees. item.title: Google's news problem
item.description: Last week, I wanted to get a bit more information about the vote in Alabama and have always had good success by starting with a Google search so did a simple search for “alabama vote.” I saw three suggested results but surprisingly the first one was a link to Breitbart. item.title: Jira analysis script
item.description: A few days ago I wrote about using average number of sprints to complete a story as a way to measure a teamâ€™s sprint efficiency. Itâ€™s available on GitHub and comes with a few additional bells and whistles.

item.title: Measuring sprint efficiency
item.description: Most startups employ some form of Agile software development and one of the most common approaches is Scrum which breaks down units of work into time based periods. I donâ€™t want to spend too much time describing either Agile or Scrum since I suspect most are familiar with the concepts but a big challenge is measuring productivity.
